Description: The Product Owner, stakeholders, and team align on the high-level purpose, goals, and vision for the product or project.
Result: A clear Product Vision Statement and business objectives.

Description: The Product Owner creates an initial, ordered list of all desired features, functions, requirements, enhancements, and fixes for the product.
The development team agrees on and documents the criteria that a Product Backlog Item must meet before it can be considered 'done' and part of an increment.
Result: A clear and shared Definition of Done.

Description: The Scrum Team collaborates to plan the work for the upcoming Sprint. It answers 'What' can be delivered and 'How' the work will be done.
Result: A Sprint Goal and a Sprint Backlog containing the selected Product Backlog Items.

Description: The development team works on the items in the Sprint Backlog to turn them into a 'Done' increment of the product. This is the main development phase.
Result: Completed and tested features according to the Sprint Backlog.

Description: A short, daily 15-minute meeting for the development team to synchronize activities, inspect progress toward the Sprint Goal, and create a plan for the next 24 hours.
Result: Team synchronization, identification of impediments, and a daily plan.

Description: An ongoing activity where the Product Owner and the Development Team add detail, estimates, and order to items in the Product Backlog.
Result: A well-defined and prioritized Product Backlog ready for future Sprints.

Description: At the end of the Sprint, the Scrum Team and stakeholders inspect the Increment. The team presents what was accomplished and gets feedback.
Result: Feedback from stakeholders and an updated Product Backlog reflecting new insights.

Description: The Scrum Team inspects itself and creates a plan for improvements to be enacted during the next Sprint. It focuses on the process, tools, and relationships.
Result: A list of actionable process improvements for the next Sprint.

Description: The sum of all the Product Backlog items completed during a Sprint and the value of the increments of all previous Sprints. At the end of a Sprint, the new Increment must be 'Done'.
Result: A potentially shippable, valuable piece of working software.

Description: The Product Owner decides whether to release the latest increment. This is a business decision based on whether the increment provides sufficient value.
Interval: As needed (can be every Sprint or after several Sprints)
Result: A decision to either release the current increment or continue development.

Description: An automated process where developers merge their code changes into a central repository frequently, after which automated builds and tests are run.
Result: A validated build and automated test results, ensuring the main codebase is always stable.

Description: An automated process that takes the successfully integrated code from CI and deploys it to a testing or production environment.
Result: A new version of the software deployed and available to users.

Description: After a release, the team monitors the software's performance, stability, and usage in production. Feedback is actively collected from users.
Result: Performance metrics, bug reports, and user feedback.

Description: The Product Owner processes the collected feedback, creating new Product Backlog Items (e.g., bug fixes, new features) to address user needs and issues.
Result: A refined and updated Product Backlog that reflects real-world user feedback.
